units.title: Dissociate brain tissue with DNase and collagenase/dispase
units.text:
1. Turn on rotating oven and allow it to heat up to 37 °C while you prepare your sample.
2. Obtain a 60 mm cell culture dish containing ~7 mL of HBSS/BSA/glucose.
3. Add 150 µL of pre-aliquoted DNase (10 mg/mL) to each dish.
4. Obtain ~250 mg of human brain tissue per sample. Document case details.
 ▲ Caution Local institutional guidelines should always be followed when using human
 source materials since they can contain blood-borne pathogens. These protocols probably
 will include training, proper engineering and personal barrier protections.
5. Place in dish containing HBSS/BSA/glucose + DNase.
 ▲ Critical step It is crucial DNase is added to the solution at this step otherwise digestion
 will be inadequate. See also the troubleshooting advice for Steps 9 and 54.
6. With a scalpel, cut tissue into small (~2 mm × 2 mm chunks) in HBSS/BSA/glucose + DNase
 solution in a sterile environment (Fig. 2).
 ▲ Critical step Ideally, dissection should occur in a cell culture biosafety cabinet. If this
 is not possible, the tissue can be dissected outside of a hood with attention paid to best
 aseptic technique.

Protocol extension

7. Distribute tissue into three 15 mL conical tubes.
 • Aliquot the tissue–buffer solution in the dish into the tubes first
 • Use extra HBSS/BSA/glucose buffer to wash the dish and make up to
 5 mL per tube
8. Add 167 µL of collagenase/dispase (100 mg/mL) to each tube. Please note,
 167 µL of collagenase/dispase per 5 mL is equivalent to 33.4 µL of solution
 per 1 mL.
9. Digest for 30 min in rotating oven at 37 °C.
 ▲ Critical step Optimal enzymatic digestion is the most important factor
 to maximize yield. Therefore, this step may need optimizing to achieve
 sufficient but not too much digestion. See also the troubleshooting advice
 for Step 54.
units.rationale: This unit contains the complete, actionable protocol for tissue dissociation and enzymatic digestion, including critical steps and precise reagent volumes.

units.title: Perform Percoll density gradient centrifugation
units.text:
10. Spin down for 5 min at 300g, 4 °C.

Percoll density gradient centrifugation
● Timing ~35 min
11. After samples have finished spinning, discard the supernatant by pouring out the liquid into
 a waste container.
 ▲ Critical step Do not aspirate the supernatant during the cell dissociation and
 digestion, as the cell pellet may be aspirated and lost.
12. Add 1 mL of HBSS/BSA/glucose and 50 µL of pre-aliquoted DNase (10 mg/mL) into each
 sample tube.
13. Gently mix/resuspend 50 times using a micropipette, taking care not to introduce bubbles,
 which may detrimentally affect the cells49.
14. Obtain two additional 15 mL conical tubes per each sample tube. For example, for three
 sample digestion tubes, obtain six tubes for Percoll filtration.
 ▲ Critical step Yield will be compromised if each digestion is not distributed into two
 Percoll tubes.
15. Dispense 4 mL of 22% Percoll into each new conical tube.
16. Carefully dispense cell suspension from each sample tube into the new conical tubes
 containing 22% Percoll in equal amounts. Use ~750 µL per tube.
 ▲ Critical step The cell suspension should be dispensed on top of
 the Percoll.
17. Spin down for 10 min at 500g, 4 °C with no deceleration.
18. Discard supernatant.
19. Reunite contents of all Percoll tubes into one tube by resuspending the cell pellet
 in the HBSS/BSA/glucose remaining after pouring out the supernatant.
20. Spin down the sample tube for 5 min at 300g, 4 °C.
21. Do not discard the remaining tubes. The small amount of cells left over after combining
 the majority of cells into one tube for the master mix can be used for unstained and DAPI
 controls (Steps 36–45).
units.rationale: This unit details the full Percoll gradient procedure with critical steps, volumes, and centrifugation parameters essential for cell separation.

units.title: Prepare master mix for immunostaining
units.text:
Master mix preparation
● Timing ~1–5 min
22. Add 200 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose into a fresh tube.
23. Add 2 µL of each antibody and 1 µL of DAPI into the tube containing 200 µL of HBSS/BSA/
 glucose per sample.
 Ab/Stain Dilution Volume
 DAPI 1:200 1 μL
 CD45 PE–Cy7 1:100 2 μL
 CD146 PE 1:100 2 μL
 ANPEP APC 1:100 2 μL
 CD31 FITC 1:100 2 μL
units.rationale: This unit provides the exact reagent volumes and dilutions for preparing the master mix used in immunostaining, a key procedural step.

units.title: Immunostain cells and prepare for FACS
units.text:
Immunostaining
● Timing ~30 min
24. After samples have finished spinning, discard supernatant.
25. Resuspend in ~200 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose.
26. Add the master mix into the tube of resuspended cells.
27. Incubate for 15 min on ice. During this sample incubation, start preparing controls by
 following Steps 36–45.
28. Wash with 5 mL of HBSS/BSA/glucose and mix.
29. Spin down for 5 min at 300g, 4 °C.
30. Discard supernatant.
 • Note the amount of supernatant remaining in the tube; 500 µL of supernatant is
 needed to resuspend
 • Add additional HBSS/BSA/glucose if below the recommended 500 µL needed to
 resuspend
31. Resuspend cells.
32. Obtain one FACS tube and a 70 µm filter.
33. With the filter over the FACS tube, dispense the resuspended cells through the filter and into
 the FACS tube.
34. Seal the tube and place on ice.
 ▲ Critical step Cells should be analyzed as soon as possible. Longer periods of
 dissociation may compromise cell viability.
35. Take samples to FACS.
units.rationale: This unit contains the complete immunostaining and preparation protocol for FACS, including incubation, washing, filtering, and critical handling instructions.

units.title: Prepare control tubes for FACS
units.text:
Control (cell) tube preparation
● Timing ~5 min
▲ Critical A total of six controls are needed (see Step 43). We recommend only using cells for
the unstained and DAPI controls because they cannot be performed with beads. This strategy
does not waste cells on fluorescence controls and optimizes yield. However, if the user prefers
not to use beads, cells can be used for all controls. In that case, a small part of the sample should
be removed for control staining.
36. Obtain the three leftover 15 mL tubes after combining sample contents into one tube (Step 19).
37. Sequentially, rinse each tube with ~500 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose and combine into one tube.
38. Obtain six fresh FACS tubes and fresh 70 µm filters.
39. With the filters on top of the FACS tubes, dispense 250 µL of combined buffer rinse into two
 of the FACS tubes.
40. Proceed to Step 41.

Control (beads) tube preparation and immunostaining
● Timing ~5 min
41. Dispense 250 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose into each of the four remaining FACS tubes.
 ▲ Critical step If using cells rather than beads as controls, add at least 10,000 cells per
tube in HBSS/BSA/glucose.
42. Add 2.5 µL of a single antibody to each single-color control tube into the FACS tubes
 containing 250 µL of HBSS/BSA/glucose.
43. For the live/dead stain, add 1.25 µL of DAPI into the FACS tubes containing 250 µL
 of combined buffer/cell rinse. One tube will be unstained.
 FACS tube Ab/stain Dilution Buffer volume Ab/stain volume
 1 DAPI 1:200 250 µL 1.25 μL
 2 CD45 PE–Cy7 1:100 250 µL 2.5 μL
 3 CD146 PE 1:100 250 µL 2.5 μL
 4 ANPEP APC 1:100 250 µL 2.5 μL
 5 CD31 FITC 1:100 250 µL 2.5 μL
 6 Unstained NA 250 µL NA

Protocol extension

44. After adding antibodies as explained in Step 43, shake the UltraComp eBead
 vial and add one drop of beads to each single-color control with the ‘Ready to Use’
 bottle. Please note, beads are designed to bind antibodies and eliminate the need
 to use cells for many controls. Therefore, do not add beads to DAPI and unstained
 controls. If cells are being used for all controls, then do not add beads to any of
 the controls.
45. Seal the tubes and place on ice.
units.rationale: This unit comprehensively details the preparation of both cell- and bead-based FACS controls with precise volumes, reagents, and critical instructions.

units.title: Perform FACS analysis and cell sorting
units.text:
FACS
● Timing ~2 h
▲ Critical Every flow cytometry system will have slightly different procedures. Here are
high-yield principles to execute a successful flow cytometry experiment.
46. Set the laser levels for each of your fluorophores with unstained and single-color controls.
47. Once the laser levels are set, then run the single-color controls again to record each
 fluorophore. After every single-color control has been run, the machine can perform
 compensation, the method of correcting for fluorescence spill over.
48. Once the laser levels are set and compensation performed, the user can draw gates to select
 sequential populations (Fig. 3a). For this strategy, we recommend first eliminating debris
 with side scatter (SSC) and forward scatter (FSC) gates. These are size and complexity
 parameters.
49. Next, eliminate doublets also with SSC or FSC.
50. Eliminate dead cells. We use DAPI but a number of live/dead stains exist in different
 fluorophores.
51. After eliminating debris, doublets and dead cells, then the user should set up
 FACS plots to select their population of interests. In our studies, endothelial
 cells were isolated as CD45−CD31+ANPEP− and mural cells were isolated as
 CD45−CD31−ANPEP+.
52. (Optional) Run additional controls to determine the true population. These may include
 ‘fluorescence minus one’ controls and unstained controls.
53. After the population has been defined, use a 100 µm nozzle to perform cell sorting.
 ▲ Critical step A smaller filter may damage the cells.
54. Translate the ‘event number’ readout from the cell sorter into a true cell number,
 a parameter termed ‘efficiency’21. This calculation may be necessary for downstream
 applications.
units.rationale: This unit provides the full FACS protocol including laser calibration, gating strategy, compensation, sorting parameters, and efficiency calculation.

units.title: Coat culture plates with collagen
units.text:
Plating cells
● Timing ~1 h
Collagen coating
● Timing ~35 min
56. Obtain a 24-well plate.
57. Calculate the amount of collagen coating solution needed. We recommend 500 µL of
collagen coating solution (0.03 mg/mL) per well.
58. Add 500 µL of collagen coating solution (0.03 mg/mL) into each well.
59. Incubate plate with collagen for 30 min at 37 °C.
60. After incubation, remove collagen coating solution from all wells.
61. Wash wells once with 1× PBS and then they are ready to use (if not using immediately,
keep PBS in the wells and store in 37 °C incubator until the sorted cells are ready to
be plated).
units.rationale: This unit contains the complete collagen coating protocol with precise volumes, concentrations, and incubation conditions for cell plating.

units.title: Plate sorted cells and initiate culture
units.text:
Plating
● Timing ~10 min
62. Spin down sorted mural and/or endothelial cell tubes (from Step 54) by centrifuging for
5 min at 300g, 4 °C.
63. After spinning, remove supernatant from microcentrifuge tubes containing cells.
64. Add 500 µL of prewarmed (37 °C) growth medium into microcentrifuge tubes containing
mural or endothelial cell pellets.
65. Resuspend.
66. Add the desired amount of cell solution into collagen-coated wells. We recommend filling
each culture well with cell solution to approximately half volume.
67. Add additional 500 µL of growth medium into wells containing cells for 1 mL total
per well.
68. Add 500 µL of 1× PBS to all other empty wells to keep them from drying.
69. Place in a 37 °C incubator.
units.rationale: This unit details the full procedure for plating sorted cells onto collagen-coated wells, including resuspension, volume guidelines, and incubation.

units.title: Change media during cell culture
units.text:
Cell culture
Changing media
● Timing ~10 min
70. Determine the amount of EGM-2 medium required for passaging based on plates and/or
wells required. Aliquot endothelial cell growth medium in a 50 mL conical tube.
71. Obtain plates with cells from 37 °C incubator.
72. Place new tip on vacuum. Aspirate the old growth medium from the plates.
73. Using a serological pipette, add 1× PBS to each plate. For a 24-well plate, we recommend
0.5 mL per well. Swirl each plate, then vacuum off the majority of PBS.
 ◆ Troubleshooting
74. Using another serological pipette, add fresh growth medium to each plate. For a 24-well
plate, we recommend 0.5 mL per well. Swirl each plate once.
75. Place plates back into the 37 °C incubator.
76. Repeat Steps 70–75 to change media approximately every other day. Monitor confluency
and when confuency has reached 75–80%, proceed to passaging (Step 77).
 ◆ Troubleshooting
units.rationale: This unit provides the complete media change protocol with volumes, techniques, and confluency criteria for maintaining cell culture.

units.title: Passage cells and prepare for FACS re-analysis
units.text:
Passaging and FACS
● Timing ~30 min plus FACS
▲ Critical Ideal cell confluency for high-yield FACS and cell health is 75–80% plate coverage.
77. Aliquot endothelial cell growth medium in a 50 mL conical tube.
78. Obtain plates with cells from 37 °C incubator.
79. Place new tip on vacuum. Vacuum out the old growth medium from the plates.
 ◆ Troubleshooting
80. Using a serological pipette, add 1× PBS to each plate. For a 24-well plate, we recommend
0.5 mL per well. Swirl each plate, then vacuum out the PBS.
 ◆ Troubleshooting
81. Using another serological
units.rationale: This unit captures the essential steps for cell passaging and preparation for potential re-analysis by FACS, including media removal and PBS washing.
